verb.description: Use or expend carelessly, extravagantly, or to no purpose.
examples: we can't afford to waste electricity
I don't use the car, so why should I waste precious money on it?

verb.description: (of a person or a part of the body) become progressively weaker and more emaciated.

examples: he seized their cattle and wasted their country

adjective.description: (of a material, substance, or byproduct) eliminated or discarded as no longer useful or required after the completion of a process.
examples: ensure that waste materials are disposed of responsibly
plants produce oxygen as a waste product

adjective.description: (of an area of land, typically in a city or town) not used, cultivated, or built on.

noun.description: An act or instance of using or expending something carelessly, extravagantly, or to no purpose.
examples: it's a waste of time trying to argue with him
they had learned to avoid waste

noun.description: Material that is not wanted; the unusable remains or byproducts of something.
A large area of barren, typically uninhabited land.
examples: the icy wastes of the Antarctic

noun.description: Damage to an estate caused by an act or by neglect, especially by a life-tenant.

phrases: Another reason I have started the practice at least on a small scale is that I hate to see so much potential going to waste.
Planning your meals ahead may save you money and lots of food and drink going to waste in the bin or down the drain
With a daily outflow of 450 million litres, that's a lot of potentially very useful water going to waste.
Did the parents who saw their kids at the protest have any concerns about their tuition dollars going to waste?
The coffee harvest has been going to waste, everyday life has been disrupted.
origin: Middle English: from Old Northern French wast(e) (noun), waster (verb), based on Latin vastus unoccupied, uncultivated.
